options.text: Weston

options.label: C
options.text: Chix

options.label: D
options.text: Mr. Forer

options.label: A
options.text: He supported Weston's claim and was excited about the discovery.

options.label: B
options.text: He was furious and thought it was a fraud.

options.label: C
options.text: He was neutral and asked for more information about the element.

options.label: D
options.text: He was confused and didn't understand the discovery.

multiple-choice.question: Why did Weston choose the name "Palladium" for the new element?

options.label: A
options.text: He named it after a planet that was discovered around the same time.

options.label: B
options.text: He named it after a famous scientist who contributed to the field.

options.label: C
options.text: He named it after a chemical property of the element.

options.label: D
options.text: He chose the name randomly.

options.label: B
options.text: It was a source of Palladium ore.

options.label: C
options.text: The name "Palladium" was inspired by the asteroid, which was considered a planet at the time.

options.label: D
options.text: Both A and C

options.label: A
options.text: He extracted it from a rock containing minerals of various noble metals through careful precipitation.

options.label: B
options.text: He created it through a chemical reaction involving other elements.

options.label: C
options.text: He discovered it in its pure form in nature.

options.label: D
options.text: He bought it from someone else who had discovered it.

options.label: A
options.text: To describe the chemical properties of Palladium and its uses.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: To explain the discovery of Palladium and its significance.

options.label: D
options.text: To sell Palladium to the public and promote its use.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of Michael Faraday's inventory of the Royal Society's collection?

options.label: A
options.text: He found that all the platinum and Palladium were accounted for and present.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: He found that some of the Palladium was missing, but the platinum was all present.

options.label: D
options.text: He found that both platinum and Palladium were missing from the collection.

options.label: A
options.text: They are labeled as platinum and have a clear identification.

options.label: B
options.text: They feel very heavy, which is consistent with the properties of platinum.

options.label: C
options.text: They are in the same box as the Palladium, which suggests a connection.

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: C

multiple-choice.question: What term does the speaker use to describe the personalized universe of information that people live in online?

options.label: A
options.text: Filter bubble

options.label: B
options.text: Personalized feed

options.label: C
options.text: Algorithmic editing

options.label: D
options.text: Web of one

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is a potential problem with algorithmic filters?

options.label: A
options.text: They only show us what we want to see.

options.label: B
options.text: They only show us what we need to see.

options.label: C
options.text: They can create an imbalance between information that is important and information that is entertaining.

options.label: D
options.text: They are only used by Facebook and Google.

multiple-choice.question: What did researchers at Netflix discover about user behavior, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: Users only watch movies that are recommended to them.

options.label: B
options.text: Users tend to watch movies that they have previously seen.

options.label: C
options.text: There is a struggle between users' future aspirational selves and their more impulsive present selves when it comes to choosing what to watch.

options.label: D
options.text: Users only watch documentaries.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is a potential consequence of relying on algorithmic filters?

options.label: A
options.text: We will be exposed to a diverse range of viewpoints and information.

options.label: B
options.text: We will only see information that is relevant to our interests.

options.label: C
options.text: We may be surrounded by "information junk food" that is not nutritious or valuable.

options.label: D
options.text: We will have more control over what we see online.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is happening in the shift from human gatekeepers to algorithmic ones?

options.label: A
options.text: The algorithms are becoming more transparent and accountable.

options.label: B
options.text: The algorithms are becoming more ethical and responsible.

options.label: C
options.text: The algorithms are taking over the role of human gatekeepers, but without the same level of ethics and responsibility.

options.label: D
options.text: The algorithms are only being used by a few companies.

multiple-choice.question: What does the speaker suggest is needed to ensure that algorithms curate the world in a responsible way?

options.label: A
options.text: More transparency and control for users, as well as a sense of civic responsibility encoded into the algorithms.

options.label: B
options.text: Less transparency and control for users.

options.label: C
options.text: More algorithms and less human gatekeepers.

options.label: D
options.text: Fewer algorithms and more human gatekeepers.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the risk if algorithms are not designed with civic responsibility in mind?

options.label: A
options.text: The internet will become more connected and inclusive.

options.label: B
options.text: The internet will become more isolated and fragmented.

options.label: C
options.text: The internet will become more transparent and accountable.

options.label: D
options.text: The internet will become more controlled and censored.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's vision for the internet?

options.label: A
options.text: A web of one, where each person is isolated in their own filter bubble.

options.label: B
options.text: A web that connects people to new ideas, new people, and different perspectives.

options.label: C
options.text: A web that is controlled by algorithms and devoid of human judgment.

options.label: D
options.text: A web that is only used by a few companies and individuals.

title: What we can learn from galaxies far, far away - Henry Lin

multiple-choice.question: What are galaxy clusters primarily composed of?

options.label: A
options.text: Individual stars

options.label: B
options.text: Collections of stars or galaxies

options.label: C
options.text: Planets and asteroids

options.label: D
options.text: Only dark matter and hot gas

multiple-choice.question: Which characteristic of galaxy clusters makes them useful for studying the universe?

options.label: A
options.text: They are relatively small and isolated

options.label: B
options.text: They are extremely massive and have strong gravity

options.label: C
options.text: They are composed of only hot gas and dark matter

options.label: D
options.text: They are representative slices of the universe at large scales

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why the hot gas in galaxy clusters is so hot?

options.label: A
options.text: The gas is heated by the stars in the galaxies

options.label: B
options.text: The gas is accelerated to great speeds by the extreme gravity of the cluster

options.label: C
options.text: The gas is composed of dark matter

options.label: D
options.text: The gas is heated by external sources, such as supernovae

multiple-choice.question: What is the mysterious component that makes up most of the universe's matter?

options.label: A
options.text: Dark energy

options.label: B
options.text: Dark matter

options.label: C
options.text: Hot gas

options.label: D
options.text: Ordinary matter

multiple-choice.question: How do scientists study the properties of dark matter in galaxy clusters?

options.label: A
options.text: By observing the light emitted by dark matter

options.label: B
options.text: By smashing particles together in a laboratory

options.label: C
options.text: By studying the effects of dark matter on the hot gas and galaxies in the cluster

options.label: D
options.text: By using computer simulations to model dark matter behavior

multiple-choice.question: What happens when galaxy clusters collide?

options.label: A
options.text: They merge into a single, more massive cluster

options.label: B
options.text: They break apart into smaller clusters

options.label: C
options.text: They create a particle accelerator that can help scientists study dark matter

options.label: D
options.text: They have no effect on the surrounding universe

multiple-choice.question: What is the name given to the cause of the accelerated expansion of the universe?

options.label: A
options.text: Dark matter

options.label: B
options.text: Dark energy

options.label: C
options.text: Ordinary matter

options.label: D
options.text: Hot gas

multiple-choice.question: How do scientists simplify the study of the large-scale structure of the universe?

options.label: A
options.text: By modeling the positions of every single galaxy and galaxy cluster

options.label: B
options.text: By tracking the biggest pieces of the universe, such as galaxy clusters

options.label: C
options.text: By ignoring the universe's structure and focusing on individual galaxies

options.label: D
options.text: By using computer simulations to model the entire universe

multiple-choice.question: What analogy does the speaker use to describe the importance of tracking galaxy clusters in understanding the universe's large-scale structure?

options.label: A
options.text: Modeling a complex system by tracking every single component

options.label: B
options.text: Modeling a complex system by tracking the largest components, such as the Titanic's largest pieces

options.label: C
options.text: Modeling the universe's structure by tracking individual galaxies

options.label: D
options.text: Modeling the universe's structure by ignoring galaxy clusters

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the ultimate goal of studying galaxy clusters and the universe?

options.label: A
options.text: To find obvious solutions to problems

options.label: B
options.text: To broaden our field of vision and inspire innovation and ingenuity

options.label: C
options.text: To focus solely on individual galaxies and ignore the larger universe

options.label: D
options.text: To prove that dark matter and dark energy do not exist

title: Why do we cry? The three types of tears - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the girl who is very sensitive and cries frequently?

options.label: A
options.text: Iris

options.label: B
options.text: Onion

options.label: C
options.text: Lily

options.label: D
options.text: Rose

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the mucus layer in the basal tears that Iris produces?

options.label: A
options.text: To keep the eye hydrated

options.label: B
options.text: To repel invasive bacteria

options.label: C
options.text: To keep the whole tear film fastened to the eye

options.label: D
options.text: To prevent the other layers from evaporating

multiple-choice.question: Which layer of the basal tears is most responsible for keeping the eye hydrated?

options.label: A
options.text: Mucus layer

options.label: B
options.text: Aqueous layer

options.label: C
options.text: Lipid layer

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary cause of Iris' irritated eyes when Onion takes off her jacket?

options.label: A
options.text: A problem with the mucus layer

options.label: B
options.text: A deficiency in the aqueous layer

options.label: C
options.text: The release of a chemical that irritates Iris' eyes

options.label: D
options.text: A combination of all the above

multiple-choice.question: What triggers Iris to produce reflex tears?

options.label: A
options.text: When she meets Onion

options.label: B
options.text: When Onion takes off her jacket, releasing a chemical that irritates Iris' eyes

options.label: C
options.text: When Iris is feeling sad or happy

options.label: D
options.text: When Iris' lacrimal glands are not functioning properly

multiple-choice.question: What is one key difference between basal tears and reflex tears?

options.label: A
options.text: Basal tears are produced in larger amounts than reflex tears

options.label: B
options.text: Reflex tears contain more antibodies in their aqueous layer than basal tears

options.label: C
options.text: Basal tears are only produced when the eye is irritated

options.label: D
options.text: Reflex tears are only produced when the eye is not irritated

multiple-choice.question: What are two possible explanations for why emotional tears may be helpful in stabilizing a person's mood?

options.label: A
options.text: They contain higher levels of stress hormones and are a social mechanism to elicit sympathy

options.label: B
options.text: They are a physical reaction to slow down breathing and heart rate

options.label: C
options.text: They contain higher levels of stress hormones and are a physical reaction to slow down breathing and heart rate

options.label: D
options.text: They are a social mechanism to elicit sympathy and a physical reaction to slow down breathing and heart rate

multiple-choice.question: What would be the independent variable, dependent variable, and control group in an experiment to test the hypothesis that emotional tears contain higher levels of stress hormones?

options.label: A
options.text: Independent variable: Emotional state; Dependent variable: Levels of stress hormones in tears; Control group: Participants who do not produce emotional tears

options.label: B
options.text: Independent variable: Levels of stress hormones in tears; Dependent variable: Emotional state; Control group: Participants who produce basal tears only

options.label: C
options.text: Independent variable: Presence or absence of emotional tears; Dependent variable: Levels of stress hormones in tears; Control group: Participants who do not produce emotional tears

options.label: D
options.text: Independent variable: Emotional state; Dependent variable: Levels of stress hormones in blood; Control group: Participants who do not produce emotional tears

multiple-choice.question: What can be said about the statement: "Emotional tears are a necessary component of the human eye's defense mechanism."

options.label: A
options.text: It is true because emotional tears contain higher levels of stress hormones

options.label: B
options.text: It is false because emotional tears are not necessary for the eye's defense mechanism

options.label: C
options.text: It is partially true because emotional tears have some role in the eye's defense mechanism

options.label: D
options.text: It is unclear because the exact function of emotional tears is still not fully understood

multiple-choice.question: If Iris produces 10 ounces of tears per day at a constant rate, and assuming 20 hours of wakefulness, how many ounces of tears does she produce per hour?

options.label: A
options.text: 0.25 ounces per hour

options.label: B
options.text: 0.33 ounces per hour

options.label: C
options.text: 0.4 ounces per hour

options.label: D
options.text: 0.5 ounces per hour

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the chemical that is released when Onion takes off her jacket, causing Iris to produce reflex tears?

options.label: A
options.text: Syn-Propanethial S-oxide

options.label: B
options.text: Sulfenic acid

options.label: C
options.text: Sulfoxide

options.label: D
options.text: Enkephalin
